awd_titl_txt: Gamma-Ray Bursts and Magnetars:  Astrophysical Connections and Probes of Fundamental Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a theoretical study about neutron stars, which are formed from the death of very massive stars that collapse and produce supernovae. Some neutron stars have very strong magnetic fields and are called "magnetars." Their extreme density makes them a great laboratory for studying fundamental physics, including the effects of Einstein's theory of general relativity. Magnetars may also have a connection to Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs), which are extremely energetic explosions in the universe. The PI will simulate merging neutron stars to see if she can create black holes and GRBs.  She will also explore the neutron star equation-of-state (EOS), which is a mathematical relationship between temperature, pressure, and energy. The PI will train and mentor a postdoctoral scholar and several undergraduate students, including women. The team will also carry out an outreach program with grade school children in the New York City area.

The science goals will be carried out through a theoretical and computational investigation of GRBs. They will computationally investigate the regime of hyper-accretion on magnetars that might form after core-collapse of the stellar progenitor and explain the presence of precursors on emission in GRBs. They will carry out fully general relativistic simulations of the merger of binary neutron stars as a possible cause of short duration GRBs. They will explore the role of the EOS in the formation of the accretion torus and jet needed to produce the GRBs, and whether there exists EOS that can lead to black hole formation after binary merger.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project had multiple science goals, under the common umbrella of

the study of Gamma-Ray Bursts and Magnetars, and their astrophysical

connections.  A special focus of the research has been devoted to study

binary neutron star mergers, which represent the ultimate targets for

multimessenger astronomy, being among the most promising sources of

gravitational waves, and, at the same time, likely accompanied

by a variety of electromagnetic counterparts across the entire

spectrum, including short gamma-ray bursts and

kilonova/macronova transients.

 

Among the most significant results of the project is a detailed

numerical investigation of the fate of the remnant compact object

resulting from a binary neutron star merger, and the astrophysical

implications for the equation of state of dense matter.  Using General

Relativistic MagnetoHydrodynamic simulations, we presented the first

detailed study of binary neutron mergers forming a long-lived neutron

star, and studied how the structure of the neutron star remnant, the

rotation profile, the accretion disk, the magnetic field evolution and

amplification, and the ejection of matter depend on the equation of

state of the neutron star.

 

Following the detection of the watershed event GW170817/GRB170817, the

first astrophysical source detected in gravitational waves and

multiwavelength electromagnetic radiation, we performed a detailed

modeling aimed at unveiling the structure of the emitting region.  We

numerically studied the propagation of a jet into the ejecta of a

double neutron star merger, and the resulting afterglow radiation, all

the way from the prompt gamma-rays to the late radio afterglow.  Our

results confirmed a single origin for binary neutron star mergers and

short gamma-ray bursts: GW170817 produced a structured outflow with a highly

relativistic core and a canonical short gamma-ray burst.

 

Broader Impacts: The variety of physics/astrophysics/numerical topics and

techniques involved by this research project have made it ideal for the

involvment of students at all levels, including undergraduates.

The PI has been especially focused to work with underrepresented minorities

in science.
